info.title: _(WRIA Boundaries ALL)
info.body:
_(WRIA 9 is comprised of the Green River and Duwamish River Watersheds. It aso includes the nearshore habitat and small drainages along Elliott Bay (downtown Seattle), plus the Puget Sound shoreline along West Seattle, Burien, Normandy Park, Des Moines and Federal Way, as well as all of Vashon Island.

A natural watershed is the total land area draining into a river, lake, or Puget Sound defined by its ridgelines. Water Resource Inventory Areas (WRIAs) are administrative units authorized under the Water Resources Act of 1971. These boundaries, which can include more than one watershed and many sub-basins, help resource managers, planners, and policy makers improve collaborative decision making around salmon recovery, farms, flooding, forestry, and stormwater management.

The Washington State Department of Ecology was given the responsibility for the development and management of these administrative and planning boundaries. There are 62 "Water Resource Inventory Areas" across the state.)

mw.description: _(Individuals can pledge to live more sustainably)

mwfeatured.description: _(Community members can report on projects in their neighborhoods)

mw-featured-projects.description: _(Teachers can report on their classroom's activities)

fields.name: title
fields.prompt: _(Project Name (It helps to incorporate your school name along with a descriptive title of your impact project. If you had multiple projects generated by individuals or teams of students you might name the collection “Student Impact Projects from Grade 9 Biology, Greenworld High School.”))

fields.name: leaders
fields.placeholder: _(Teacher’s name, team of colleagues, or student names)

fields.name: goal
fields.placeholder: _(One clear sentence. Best to identify the intended impact in the goal statement.)

fields.name: background
fields.placeholder: _(One concise paragraph on why this issue is a problem or a community priority. What's been done? What’s needed?)

fields.name: partners-stakeholders
fields.placeholder: _(Who are the stakeholders and what is their relationship to this problem/solution?)

fields.name: action
fields.placeholder: _(Concise outline of steps taken that show how the solution was designed, how data were collected, and how stakeholders were identified, consulted, or informed. Insert photos to help tell your story. If possible, be sure to describe the actual impact of your project in relation to community sustainability goals and performance measures. Consider embedding links to community goals or metrics. What are your next steps or recommendations for future classes?)

content.label: _(Turn off water when brushing my teeth)
_(Replaced old toilets with water efficient toilets)
_(Use efficient irrigation systems for lawn or garden)
_(Use mostly native plants to conserve water)
_(Let the lawn go dormant in summer)
_(Scoop the poop and put in the trash)
_(Never dump household chemicals, paint or car oil down storm drain)
_(Rake leaves and litter out from my curb and storm drain)
_(I only flush the 4 P's - Pee, Poop, Toilet Paper, Puke)
_(I never flush wipes, diapers, nursing pads)
_(I do not put F.O.G down the drain (fat, oil, grease))
_(I do not use cleansers with plastic “cleansing beads”)
_(I wash fleece and synthetic materials in bags to prevent micro plastic waste)
_(Upgrade weather stripping on windows and doors)
_(Invest 100% in (Seattle Green Up) or (PSE Green Power))

place_detail.name: location_type
place_detail.label: _(I will commute on low carbon transit)

content.label: _(Mostly walk commute (to school, work, or for errands))
_(Grow food to eat in my garden)
_(Subscribe to a CSA - Consumer Supported Agriculture)
_(Regularly shop at a local Farmer's Market)
_(Shop in grocery stores mostly for local and organic foods)
_(Regularly volunteer to remove invasive plants from streams and rivers)
_(Regularly volunteer to plant and maintain native plants in streams and rivers)
_(Regularly volunteer to spot and count spawning salmon)
_(Discovery Elementary School -- Lake Washington School District)
_(Eastside Montessori Education Foundation dba Arbor Schools)

content: • Sign in (use the button on the top right)
• Request access to be an administrator.
If you're having trouble signing in send a message to feedback@heyduwamish.org and we'll fix it right away!
Once you've been approved as an admin, you'll have the ability to edit certain sites on the map
If you don't see an "Edit this post" button, you are either not signed in or you don't have permission to edit that particular site.
• You can use the Edit this post button to cancel your changes and go back.
• Hit the Remove button to remove the site from the map.
• Save a post in draft mode by setting it from Published to Not published. When a post is in draft mode, it will not show up on the map. Only admins who are signed in can see it.
You can also add new featured sites, directly to the map!
• Hit "Add a report" as if you were adding a community report.
• Select the option to "Add a featured site"
You can add a marker and select a marker symbol, draw a line, or draw a polygon.
The content editor offers you a variety of formatting options such as:
• Header selection for large or mid-sized page headers
• Rich text bold, italics, underline, and color selection
Hit the Save button if you're ready to publish. Otherwise, you can store it as a draft by setting the state to unpublished at the top of the editor.
Please reach out if you need any help.

Seed funding provided by the Puget Sound Stewardship and Mitigation Fund, a community grantmaking fund created by Puget Soundkeeper Alliance and administered by the Rose Foundation for Communities and the Environment.
Additional funding provided by Cascade Water Alliance in partnership with Sustainability Ambassadors.
Back to the map

Add your classroom reports to the map! Let your students and stakeholders track and visualize the positive impact of their classroom and community projects. Need admin support to get started? Just ask.
Click the button below, then choose the Featured Project cateory to add your report.
REPORT IT!
